content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS." is a concise summary of the section's title and its purpose. The Congressional Hunger Fellows Act of 2001, named after Bill Emerson and George T. (Mickey) Leland, recognizes the critical need for individuals dedicated to addressing hunger and implementing solutions. The fellowship program honors the memory of Mr. Emerson and Mr. Leland, who showed compassion for the needy and promoted equality and justice. They maintained a friendship regardless of political differences and worked together to inspire future leaders in humanitarian service. Establishment of the board of trustees. The Congressional Hunger Fellows Program is established as an independent entity supervised by a Board of Trustees with 6 voting members appointed by congressional leaders. The minority leader of the Senate appoints 1 member to the Board, with the Executive Director serving as a nonvoting member. Board members serve a 4-year term, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Vacancies do not affect the Board's power to carry out the program. The individual appointed to fill a vacancy on the Board serves for the remainder of the predecessor's term. The Board elects a Chairperson at its first meeting. Board members do not receive compensation but may be reimbursed for travel expenses. The Board elects a Chairperson at its first meeting. Members do not receive compensation but may be reimbursed for travel expenses. SEC. 3. PURPOSES; AUTHORITY OF PROGRAM. The Program aims to encourage future leaders to pursue careers in humanitarian service, increase awareness of public service, and provide training opportunities. It is authorized to develop fellowships like the Bill Emerson Hunger Fellowship and the Mickey Leland Hunger Fellowship. The Bill Emerson Hunger Fellowship provides education and training to improve humanitarian conditions and help individuals suffering from hunger in the United States. This includes direct service training with community organizations and policy development experience in governmental or nonprofit entities. The Mickey Leland Hunger Fellowship focuses on addressing international hunger and humanitarian needs. Fellowships are awarded for 12 to 24 months through a nationwide competition, targeting individuals with a passion for humanitarian service and potential for a career in this field. Each recipient receives an award amount for their participation. Each individual awarded a fellowship under this subsection shall receive an educational award and living allowance as determined by the Program. An individual awarded a fellowship from the Bill Emerson Hunger Fellowship shall be known as an "Emerson Fellow", and from the Mickey Leland Hunger Fellowship as a "Leland Fellow". The Program shall conduct periodic evaluations of the Bill Emerson and Mickey Leland Hunger Fellowships. The Congressional Hunger Fellows Trust Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States, consisting of appropriated amounts, investments made by the Secretary of the Treasury, and returns on investments. The Fund is used for expenditures and audits. The Secretary of the Treasury transfers necessary sums to the Program from specified amounts. However, the Secretary cannot transfer funds appropriated to the Fund. The Comptroller General conducts annual audits of the Program's accounts and submits results to Congress. The Comptroller General conducts annual audits of the Program's accounts and submits results to Congress. SEC. 6. STAFF; POWERS OF PROGRAM. The Board appoints an Executive Director to administer the Program, who may appoint staff with Board approval. The Executive Director's compensation is capped at the rate of basic pay for level III of the Executive Schedule. The Executive Director cannot serve as Chairperson of the Board. The Program appoints individuals at a rate not exceeding GS-15 pay level. The Program can accept gifts, bequests, and hire experts for its functions. The Program can provide temporary services under section 3109 of title 5, United States Code, at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the maximum annual pay for GS-15. It has the authority to contract with and compensate government and private agencies or individuals without following certain statutes. Additionally, the Program can make necessary expenditures to fulfill the provisions of the Act. The Board must submit an annual report on Program activities to the Secretary of Agriculture and Congress by December 31. $18,000,000 is authorized for the Act's implementation.
